member.name: T:Jil.DateTimeFormat
member.summary: Specifies the format of DateTimes and TimeSpans produced or expected by Jil.

member.name: F:Jil.DateTimeFormat.NewtonsoftStyleMillisecondsSinceUnixEpoch
member.summary:
Obsolete: Use MicrosoftStyleMillisecondsSinceUnixEpoch instead
DateTimes will be formatted as "\/Date(##...##)\/" where ##...## is the number of milliseconds since the unix epoch (January 1st, 1970 UTC).
TimeSpans will be formatted as "days.hours:minutes:seconds.fractionalSeconds"

member.name: F:Jil.DateTimeFormat.MillisecondsSinceUnixEpoch
member.summary:
DateTimes will be formatted as ##...##, where ##...## is the number of milliseconds since the unix epoch (January 1st, 1970 UTC).
This is format can be passed directly to JavaZcript's Date constructor.
TimeSpans will be formatted as ##...##, where ##...## is the TotalMilliseconds property of the TimeSpan.

member.name: F:Jil.DateTimeFormat.SecondsSinceUnixEpoch
member.summary:
DateTimes will be formatted as ##...##, where ##...## is the number of seconds since the unix epoch (January 1st, 1970 UTC).
TimeSpans will be formatted as ##...##, where ##...## is the TotalSeconds property of the TimeSpan.

member.name: F:Jil.DateTimeFormat.ISO8601
member.summary:
DateTimes will be formatted as "yyyy-MM-ddThh:mm:ssZ" where yyyy is the year, MM is the month (starting at 01), dd is the day (starting at 01), hh is the hour (starting at 00, continuing to 24), mm is the minute (start at 00), and ss is the second (starting at 00).
Examples: 2011-07-14T19:43:37Z 2012-01-02T03:04:05Z
TimeSpans will be formatted as ISO8601 durations.
Examples: P123DT11H30M2.3S

member.name: F:Jil.DateTimeFormat.RFC1123
member.summary:
DateTimes will be formatted as "ddd, dd MMM yyyy HH:mm:ss GMT" where ddd is the abbreviation of a day, dd is the day (starting at 01), MMM is the abbreviation of a month, yyyy is the year, HH is the hour (starting at 00, continuing to 24), mm is the minute (start at 00), and ss is the second (starting at 00), and GMT is a literal indicating the timezone (always GMT).
Examples: Thu, 10 Apr 2008 13:30:00 GMT Tue, 10 Mar 2015 00:14:34 GMT
TimeSpans will be formatted as "days.hours:minutes:seconds.fractionalSeconds"

member.name: F:Jil.DateTimeFormat.MicrosoftStyleMillisecondsSinceUnixEpoch
member.summary:
DateTimes will be formatted as "\/Date(##...##)\/" where ##...## is the number of milliseconds since the unix epoch (January 1st, 1970 UTC). See: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb299886.aspx
Example: "\/Date(628318530718)\/"
TimeSpans will be formatted as "days.hours:minutes:seconds.fractionalSeconds"

member.name: T:Jil.DeserializationException
member.summary: An exception thrown when Jil encounters an error when deserializing a stream.

member.name: P:Jil.DeserializationException.Position
member.summary:
The position in the TextReader where an error occurred, if it is available.
This is meant for debugging purposes only, as exactly when Jil decides to abandon deserialization and throw an exception is an implementation detail.

member.name: P:Jil.DeserializationException.SnippetAfterError
member.summary:
A snippet of text immediately after an error occurred.
This is meant for debugging purposes only, as exactly when Jil decides to abandon deserialization and throw an exception is an implementation detail.

member.name: P:Jil.DeserializationException.EndedUnexpectedly
member.summary:
Whether or not the TextReader ended sooner than Jil expected.
This is meant for debugging purposes only, as exactly when Jil decides to abandon deserialization and throw an exception is an implementation detail.

member.name: M:Jil.Common.ExtensionMethods.IsAnonymouseClass(System.Type)
member.summary:
HACK: This is a best effort attempt to divine if a type is anonymous based on the language spec.
Reference section 7.6.10.6 of the C# language spec as of 2012/11/19
It checks: - is a class - descends directly from object - has [CompilerGenerated] - has a single constructor - that constructor takes exactly the same parameters as its public properties - all public properties are not writable - has a private field for every public property - overrides Equals(object) - overrides GetHashCode()

member.name: T:Jil.InfiniteRecursionException
member.summary:
An exception throw when Jil suspects it's in an infinite recursive case.
Note that this is detected heuristically, exactly how many recursions must occur before it is thrown depends on the configuration and version of Jil, as well as the object being serialized.

member.name: T:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute
member.summary:
Alternative to using [DataMember] and [IgnoreDataMember], for when their use isn't possible.
When applied to a property or field, allows configuration of the name (de)serialized, whether to (de)serialize at all, and the primitive type to treat an enum type as.
Takes precedence over [DataMember] and [IgnoreDataMember].

member.name: M:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new JilDirectiveAttribute

member.name: M:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Create a new JilDirectiveAttribute, with a name override.

member.name: M:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a new JilDirectiveAttribute, optionally ignoring the decorated member.

member.name: M:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Create a new JilDirectiveAttribute, treating the decorate member of an enum type as the given primitive type (ie. byte, sbyte, short, ushort, int, uint, long, or ulong).

member.name: P:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute.Ignore
member.summary: If true, the decorated member will not be serialized or deserialized.

member.name: P:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute.Name
member.summary: If non-null, the decorated member's name in serialization will match the value of Name.

member.name: P:Jil.JilDirectiveAttribute.TreatEnumerationAs
member.summary: If true and the member annotated is an enum, will cause Jil to convert the enum to the appropriate primitive type before serializing; and expect that primitive type when deserializing, converting back to the enum when constructing the final object.

member.name: T:Jil.JSON
member.summary: Fast JSON serializer.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Sets the Options object that Jil will use to calls of Serialize(Dynamic) and Deserialize(Dynamic) if no Options object is provided.
By default, Jil will use the Options.Default object.
The current default Options can be retrieved with GetDefaultOptions().

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.GetDefaultOptions
member.summary:
Gets the Options object that Jil will use to calls of Serialize(Dynamic) and Deserialize(Dynamic) if no Options object is provided.
By default, Jil will use the Options.Default object.
The default Options can be set with SetDefaultOptions(Options options).

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.SerializeDynamic(System.Object,System.IO.TextWriter,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Serializes the given data to the provided TextWriter.
Pass an Options object to configure the particulars (such as whitespace, and DateTime formats) of the produced JSON. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.
Unlike Serialize, this method will inspect the Type of data to determine what serializer to invoke. This is not as fast as calling Serialize with a known type.
Objects with participate in the DLR will be serialized appropriately, all other types will be serialized via reflection.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.SerializeDynamic(System.Object,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Serializes the given data, returning it as a string.
Pass an Options object to configure the particulars (such as whitespace, and DateTime formats) of the produced JSON. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.
Unlike Serialize, this method will inspect the Type of data to determine what serializer to invoke. This is not as fast as calling Serialize with a known type.
Objects with participate in the DLR will be serialized appropriately, all other types will be serialized via reflection.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.Serialize``1(``0,System.IO.TextWriter,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Serializes the given data to the provided TextWriter.
Pass an Options object to configure the particulars (such as whitespace, and DateTime formats) of the produced JSON. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.Serialize``1(``0,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Serializes the given data, returning the output as a string.
Pass an Options object to configure the particulars (such as whitespace, and DateTime formats) of the produced JSON. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.Deserialize(System.IO.TextReader,System.Type,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Deserializes JSON from the given TextReader as the passed type.
This is equivalent to calling Deserialize<T>(TextReader, Options), except without requiring a generic parameter. For true dynamic deserialization, you should use DeserializeDynamic instead.
Pass an Options object to specify the particulars (such as DateTime formats) of the JSON being deserialized. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.Deserialize(System.String,System.Type,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Deserializes JSON from the given string as the passed type.
This is equivalent to calling Deserialize<T>(string, Options), except without requiring a generic parameter. For true dynamic deserialization, you should use DeserializeDynamic instead.
Pass an Options object to specify the particulars (such as DateTime formats) of the JSON being deserialized. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.Deserialize``1(System.IO.TextReader,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Deserializes JSON from the given TextReader.
Pass an Options object to specify the particulars (such as DateTime formats) of the JSON being deserialized. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.Deserialize``1(System.String,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Deserializes JSON from the given string.
Pass an Options object to specify the particulars (such as DateTime formats) of the JSON being deserialized. If omitted Options.Default is used, unless JSON.SetDefaultOptions(Options) has been called with a different Options object.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.DeserializeDynamic(System.IO.TextReader,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Deserializes JSON from the given TextReader, inferring types from the structure of the JSON text.
For the best performance, use the strongly typed Deserialize method when possible.

member.name: M:Jil.JSON.DeserializeDynamic(System.String,Jil.Options)
member.summary:
Deserializes JSON from the given string, inferring types from the structure of the JSON text.
For the best performance, use the strongly typed Deserialize method when possible.

member.name: T:Jil.Options
member.summary: Configuration options for Jil serialization, passed to the JSON.Serialize method.

member.name: M:Jil.Options.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,Jil.DateTimeFormat,System.Boolean,Jil.UnspecifiedDateTimeKindBehavior)
member.summary:
Configuration for Jil serialization options.
Available options: prettyPrint - whether or not to include whitespace and newlines for ease of reading excludeNulls - whether or not to write object members whose value is null jsonp - whether or not the serialized json should be valid for use with JSONP dateFormat - the style in which to serialize DateTimes and TimeSpans includeInherited - whether or not to serialize members declared by an objects base types

member.name: M:Jil.Options.ToString
member.summary:
Returns a string representation of this Options object.
The format of this may change at any time, it is only meant for debugging.

member.name: M:Jil.Options.GetHashCode
member.summary: Returns a code that uniquely identifies this set of Options.

member.name: M:Jil.Options.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns true if two Options are equal, and false otherwise

member.name: T:Jil.UnspecifiedDateTimeKindBehavior
member.summary: Specifies what to convert a DateTime to if it has DateTimeKind.Unspecified as it's Kind.

member.name: F:Jil.UnspecifiedDateTimeKindBehavior.IsLocal
member.summary:
Indicates that the DateTime is actually in the Local time.
This is the default.

member.name: F:Jil.UnspecifiedDateTimeKindBehavior.IsUTC
member.summary: Indicates that the DateTime is actually in UTC time.

member.name: M:Jil.Common.Utils.GetAnonymousNameToConstructorMap(System.Type)
member.summary:
This returns a map of "name of member" => [Type of member, index of argument to constructor]. We need this for anonymous types because we can't set properties (they're read-only).
How this works is kind of fun.
By spec, the arguments to the constructor are in declaration order for an anonymous type. So: new { A, B, C } => new SomeType(A a, B b, C c)
However there is no way to get declaration order via reflection, it's just not data that's preserved. Furthermore, the names of backing fields for those read-only properties are not defined by the spec.
So I got clever.
This method decompiles the constructor to find out which fields are set by which arguments (by index). It then decompiles all properties to find out which fields back which properties. Then it finally works backwards from each property, taking the property's name type and using it's backing field to lookup which index to pass it in as when constructing the anonymous object.
